Comparing the pollution levels in America and Europe to that of India is only comfortable to those who haven't seen both and do their own judgment. Indias problems have been there not just in Delhi but all over. The ground water pollution, garbage burning, leaf burning have been there since 80s. Though much has changed, what has really changed is access to information  has compounded. Pride in our nation is  a lot more than what it was in the 80s. A pride that was the domain of the doggedly patriotic has consumed much of the population. Thanks to better leadership, invention, education economy combined with a great respect India has earned abroad..But that shouldn't fool us in convincing ourselves, our problems are only slightly more than the America's and Europe's problems. It's exponentially more. It's a fact that was easier to digest a decade ago, but today with all that prejudice coming from rightfully earned pride, it's easier said than done. Let's get our heads down and get to work. We can't copy the west's way of becoming developed. Let's leave that experiment to China as I think it's pretty obvious its a failed model. But instead we need to address our problems our own way. I'm no expert at all, but our built environment needs to be of indigenous materials, methods and  building science. We can't copy the west's model of concrete, rebar, insulation  and glazing. We can't produce and consume those materials in such proportions, not being able to recycle them at the same rate the west does. Ifs a problem in China and they don't realize it. Their state controlled media won't let them realize. They'd made to beleive, they live a better life than the rest of the world. It's a long shot to change that behaviour. So let's not go there. Only example setting by India may change the course of this ecological disaster in Asia and Africa as our problems are more relatable. West had their problems and they will solve it by themselves. We need to solve ours. And good part is we are capable. More than what we or world thought we are capable of.

Fixing Delhi's air pollution issue is a complex challenge that requires a multi-pronged approach. Some measures Delhi can take include:1. Improving public transportation: Expanding and enhancing the metro system, buses, and promoting non-motorized transport options can reduce the reliance on private vehicles.2. Implementing stricter emissions standards: Enforcing stringent emissions standards for vehicles and industries can help reduce pollution levels.3. Promoting electric vehicles: Encouraging the adoption of electric vehicles can significantly reduce vehicular emissions.4. Reducing industrial emissions: Enforcing pollution control measures in industries and relocating polluting industries away from residential areas can help.5. Managing construction and road dust: Implementing dust control measures at construction sites and on roads can reduce particulate matter in the air.6. Increasing green spaces: Promoting urban forestry, parks, and green building practices can improve air quality.7. Reducing crop burning: Addressing crop residue burning through incentives and technology can help mitigate seasonal air pollution.8. Public awareness and behavior change: Educating the public about the health impacts of air pollution and promoting responsible behavior can lead to positive changes.9. Monitoring and data transparency: Implementing robust air quality monitoring systems and making data publicly available can help track progress.10. Regional cooperation: Collaborating with neighboring states to address shared sources of pollution, such as stubble burning, is essential.These measures need to be implemented comprehensively and in a sustained manner, and public support and participation are crucial for their success.

Air pollution is a critical issue affecting millions in urban areas, particularly in cities like Delhi. While China has made significant investments in large air purifiers to combat this problem, similar initiatives could be beneficial in Delhi as well. Wealthy residents of Delhi, including millionaires, have the resources to contribute to community welfare. By coming together to fund the installation of large air purifiers, they can make a substantial impact on local air quality. This collective effort could inspire others to join and create a ripple effect throughout the city.  If citizens take the initiative to improve air quality through such projects, it may prompt government officials and politicians to recognize the urgency of the situation and take further action. Public pressure and visible community efforts can lead to more comprehensive policies aimed at reducing pollution. Encouraging collaboration among affluent individuals for social service initiatives like installing air purifiers could not only enhance public health but also motivate governmental bodies to prioritize environmental issues. Affluent individuals often have access to networks that can facilitate large-scale projects. By encouraging collaboration among these individuals, we can create impactful initiatives that not only focus on planting trees but also promote sustainable practices within communities. This could involve forming partnerships with environmental organizations or investing in local community projects aimed at reforestation.The youth represent a significant portion of the population and possess unique capabilities to drive change through social media and grassroots movements. Instead of spending time on activities like dancing on social media reels, young people should be encouraged to engage in environmental activism. This could include organizing local tree-planting events, participating in educational campaigns about the importance of trees, or advocating for policies that support environmental sustainability.TAKE ACTION INSTEAD JUST TALKING ABOUT IT!!!! While China has made significant investments in large air purifiers to combat this problem, similar initiatives could be beneficial in Delhi as well. Wealthy residents of Delhi, including millionaires, have the resources to contribute to community welfare. By coming together to fund the installation of large air purifiers, they can make a substantial impact on local air quality. This collective effort could inspire others to join and create a ripple effect throughout the city.  If citizens take the initiative to improve air quality through such projects, it may prompt government officials and politicians to recognize the urgency of the situation and take further action. Public pressure and visible community efforts can lead to more comprehensive policies aimed at reducing pollution. Encouraging collaboration among affluent individuals for social service initiatives like installing air purifiers could not only enhance public health but also motivate governmental bodies to prioritize environmental issues. Affluent individuals often have access to networks that can facilitate large-scale projects. By encouraging collaboration among these individuals, we can create impactful initiatives that not only focus on planting trees but also promote sustainable practices within communities. This could involve forming partnerships with environmental organizations or investing in local community projects aimed at reforestation.The youth represent a significant portion of the population and possess unique capabilities to drive change through social media and grassroots movements. Instead of spending time on activities like dancing on social media reels, young people should be encouraged to engage in environmental activism. This could include organizing local tree-planting events, participating in educational campaigns about the importance of trees, or advocating for policies that support environmental sustainability.TAKE ACTION INSTEAD JUST TALKING ABOUT IT!!!! The Silent Threat of Air Pollution and the Power of Wearable Air Purifier MasksAir pollution is an invisible enemy, posing severe risks to our health every day. From fine particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10) to harmful gases like carbon monoxide and nitrogen dioxide, the air we breathe often carries toxic elements that can lead to respiratory issues, allergies, asthma, cardiovascular diseases, and even long-term conditions like lung cancer. Prolonged exposure to polluted air is especially harmful to children, the elderly, and individuals with pre-existing health conditions.In such challenging times, protecting yourself is not just a choice—it’s a necessity. Smoke from stubble burning in North India is blown south from mountains out to sea - as it passes over New Delhi the smoke traps all the additional ppm smoke, dust, contaminant particles close to the ground - now its trapped - on repeat until rains come and burning season commences. Just the cessation of stubble burning would be an enormous improvement two fold - to not trap pollutants already occurring in Delhi, and to not add pollutants to the air. However, it's also the cheapest, simplest method to fertilize fields and remove stalks; and the most habit engrained process for doing so. I haven't see the decomposing tech before, or considered the enormous effect covering construction sites would have on air quality. Appreciate these being brought to the fore. Cheers.

What people don't understand is that while stubble fires are a very key cause (second highest contributors), thermal power plants such as coal are actually the primary factors why there is so much pollution and AQI degradation. But due to heavy business lobbying, the mainstream media doesn't highlight this. Promoting and using more EVs will only cause this issue to further rise in the long run.Additionally, shutting a majority of these coal plants or moving them to better areas while simultaneously upgrading the technology of the existing plants to run more efficiently and creating mechanisms to filter/trap the emissions at the source itself is what is going to bring change.Lastly, we should gradually be moving towards renewable energy sources such as Wind and Solar to meet our power generation requirements.

As Delhi is choking under toxic air, with AQI (Air Quality Index) hovering around “severe” category (401-500); touching 494 mark on Monday, making it the world’s most polluted capital city, let us try to understand the measures that should be taken to address the issue. The country's capital getting engulfed in thick smog during winter year after year, is not only detrimental to public health, but also impacting India’s reputation on the global stage. First, let us see the solutions discussed by the anchor:  i) Better tracking of farm fires; ii) using alternatives to stubble burning; iii) encouraging purchase and use of EVs as well as hybrid vehicles; iv) covering dust-generating construction materials and demolition sites; v) spending more on new and filtering technologies; vi) full utilization of central govt’s fund allotted for “National Clean Air Programme”.“Cleaning Delhi’s air - and that of other Indian cities – requires all-year-round action”, with proper planning, monitoring, and related investment. Infact, it should be a focal point in govt’s agenda and part of policy-making. To combat the issue of soaring air pollution, concerned authorities should find out solutions which have a “long-term, sustainable approach based on science”, along with preventive measures. According to experts, the following actions should be taken to address the burning issue of air pollution: i) use of cleaner modes of commuting; ii) increased use of public transport; iii) greater scrutiny over industrial emissions; iv) incentivise households to transition to green cooking fuels; v) curb on use of coals in hotels; vi) initiate artificial rains; vii) increasing use of BS VI vehicles, as well as, use of the more refined BS VI fuel in BS IV vehicles (as far as practicable); viii) use of water spray and initiating more plantation drives; ix) promote the use of bicycles, and if possible, create separate tracks for that, etc.This recurring problem could not only become an election issue in the upcoming Delhi Assembly polls, but should be raised in the parliament as well.   As India is planning to host COP 33 (Conference of Parties) Climate Summit in 2028, resolving the capital’s air pollution problem should be a top priority, and needs comprehensive and concerted efforts from both the Delhi government and the Centre.

Instead of burning wheat stubble, American farmers use several alternative methods to manage it effectively:No-Till Farming: This method involves leaving the stubble on the field and planting the next crop directly into the residue. It helps improve soil health by reducing erosion, increasing water retention, and enhancing soil organic matter.Tillage: Some farmers choose to till the soil, which involves breaking up and mixing the stubble into the soil. This can help control weeds and prepare the soil for the next crop, but it can also lead to soil erosion and loss of organic matter.Mowing: Mowing the stubble can reduce weed seed production and make the field more manageable. This method is often used in combination with other practices.Herbicides: Farmers may use herbicides to control weeds in wheat stubble fields. This can be an effective way to manage weed growth without disturbing the soil.Cover Crops: Planting cover crops, such as legumes or grasses, can help improve soil health, reduce erosion, and suppress weeds.Baling: Some farmers bale the stubble and sell it as livestock feed or use it for bedding material.Composting: Composting the stubble can create valuable organic matter that can be used to improve soil fertility.Bio-Enzymes: Some farmers use bio-enzymes to decompose the stubble, turning it into manure and improving soil quality.Each method has its benefits and drawbacks, and the choice often depends on the specific conditions of the farm and the goals of the farmer.

It is overly simplistic to hold the Delhi government solely accountable for the city’s persistent pollution crisis. While I am not an advocate for the AAP government, it is important to acknowledge that pollution in Delhi is intricately tied to contributions from neighboring cities such as Noida, Gurgaon, Faridabad, and Ghaziabad. These regions, with their sprawling industrial estates, vehicular emissions, and thermal power plants, play a significant role in exacerbating Delhi’s environmental woes.The Delhi government lacks jurisdiction over these areas, and without active cooperation and accountability from the governments of Uttar Pradesh and Haryana, any meaningful resolution remains elusive. Instead of addressing the root causes collaboratively, the blame game continues unabated, leaving Delhi and the wider NCR region to bear the brunt of deteriorating air and water quality. This stalemate ensures that the crisis persists, as political expediency triumphs over collective responsibility.

Why Staying in India Feels HopelessIndia, a country that once seemed full of promise, now feels like a place where dreams come to die. Every day, millions of us wake up hoping for change, but instead, we’re met with the same chaos, broken systems, and empty promises. It’s heartbreaking, but for many, the only real solution is to leave. Here’s why staying feels unbearable:1. Politics: The political scene is a disaster. Corruption runs deep, and leaders care more about their vote banks than the people they’re supposed to serve. They talk about progress, but where is it? All we get are excuses and blame-shifting, while real issues—our issues—are ignored.2. Education: Our education system is failing us. Schools and colleges don’t prepare us for the real world; they train us to cram, pass exams, and then struggle to find relevance in a competitive global market. Parents sacrifice everything for their children’s education, only for them to realize they need to leave the country to truly succeed.3. Jobs: Where are the jobs? Even after years of education and hard work, so many of us are stuck in underpaying or unstable roles. It’s disheartening to watch talent and ambition go to waste while nepotism and favoritism thrive.4. Infrastructure: Roads full of potholes, constant power cuts, and cities choking on traffic. This isn’t progress—it’s survival. And if you’re in rural India, good luck finding even the most basic infrastructure.5. Healthcare: Getting sick in India is a gamble with your life. Public hospitals are overcrowded and poorly managed, while private healthcare is so expensive it can ruin families. What’s worse is seeing politicians flying abroad for treatment while we’re left to fend for ourselves.6. Society: Our people can be kind, but society often feels like a trap. We’re constantly judged—by our neighbors, extended families, even strangers. There’s no room for individuality, no space to live freely without someone dictating how we should behave.7. Air Quality: Breathing has become a health risk in most cities. The government talks about sustainability, but where’s the action? Children grow up inhaling poison, and we’re told to accept this as normal.8. Taxes: We work hard, we pay our taxes, and yet we see nothing in return. Where does all the money go? It’s infuriating to contribute so much and still live without proper roads, clean water, or quality public services.9. Quality of Life: Life here feels like an endless grind. We work tirelessly but rarely feel like we’re truly living. There’s no time to relax, no space to breathe, and no sense of security for the future.10. Future Outlook: And speaking of the future—what hope is there? Inflation keeps rising, opportunities keep shrinking, and the country feels like it’s on a downward spiral. If this is today, what will tomorrow look like?More Reasons to Leave11. Corruption: From the smallest government office to the highest levels of power, corruption is everywhere. It’s exhausting to fight a system that seems designed to exploit us at every turn.12. Public Safety: Crime is rising, and justice is painfully slow. Women are unsafe, children are unsafe, and even speaking out against the system feels dangerous. How can we live like this?13. Environmental Neglect: Look at our rivers, our forests—they’re being destroyed in the name of "development." The environment isn’t just being ignored; it’s being sacrificed for profits and PR stunts.14. Freedom of Speech: Try expressing your opinions, and you’re immediately attacked—either online or in real life. Criticizing the government or questioning the system has become a risky endeavor.15. Talent Waste: So many bright, talented people have no choice but to leave. It’s painful to watch our best minds—our friends, our family—move abroad because they know their potential will never be valued here.16. Urban Chaos: Our cities are overcrowded, filthy, and collapsing under their own weight. Every day feels like a battle just to get through the traffic, the pollution, and the lack of basic services.17. Global Image vs. Reality: The world is shown a shiny, polished version of India, but we know the truth. We live it every day—the struggles, the injustices, the broken promises.The truth is, we’ve given so much to this country, and what have we gotten in return? Broken dreams, constant struggles, and a future that feels even worse than the present. Staying here feels like being stuck in quicksand—no matter how hard we try, we’re only sinking deeper.For those who can leave, it’s not about abandoning India—it’s about saving ourselves. Moving out isn’t just an opportunity; it’s a chance to finally live, to breathe, and to build a life where we’re valued, supported, and free.

This is a stubble burning issue as far as Delhi NCR is concerned.

India is the top rice exporter country in the world. It exports 3 times as much rice as the second highest rice exporting country viz. Thailand. Rice is already a highly water-intensive crop. Why do we grow it so much in surplus when it's already creating problems for us? And I'm not just talking about stubble burning but also how much pressure has been put on groundwater due to it. States like Punjab and Haryana are not geographically suited for growing rice as much as they grow it. Farmers are using electric tubewells incessantly to draw out what little of groundwater is left in these states. It is happening just because govt. has been indiscriminately giving good MSP on it over the years. And not to forget the electricity freebie given out of taxpayers' money to run those tubewells. The reason why straw burning from Punjab and Haryana has become more of a mayhem in recent years is because this particular agri cycle has been shifted to Oct-Nov by farmers due to groundwater issues in pre-monsoon season. If govt. had the political will or intent, it could've provided some incentives to promote mechanised disposal of straw or linked MSP to straw procurement from farmers but apparently that won't turn out to be a vote-magnet like the electricity freebie. High time MSP must be discouraged on paddy and instead be enhanced on crops like maize, millets, oilseeds and pulses. This will not just  discourage exorbitant paddy production which is causing collateral problems but also ensure food and nutritional security for our population which already has a very high simple carbohydrates intake.

Best solution to pollution will be manufacturing Bioethnol Plants. Raw materials for this will be agricultural wastes (Parli).Results of Bioethnol Plants are multidimensional:- Reduction in Pollution by reduced Parli burning (as more and more Parli will be consumed in plant)- Reduction in Pollution from Automobile exhaust ( since Bioethnol is cleaner fuel than traditional petrol and diesel)- increased income of farmers (by selling the Parli to Bioethnol Plants)- Lesser import of Crude petroleumAlready technology is available in India for Bioethnol production (one of such technology provider is Praj industry of Puna, and India Glycol company of Himachal Pradesh is already manufacturing it)In 2016-18 Indian Govt was urging IOCL, BPCL, HPCL to set up Bioethnol manufacturing plants. This production in Bioethnol will single-handedly solve a lot of issues ranging from-pollution-empowerment of farmer- reduction in Fossil fuels dependency- Towards Atmanirbharta

Air pollution is a critical issue affecting millions in urban areas, particularly in cities like Delhi. While China has made significant investments in large air purifiers to combat this problem, similar initiatives could be beneficial in Delhi as well. Wealthy residents of Delhi, including millionaires, have the resources to contribute to community welfare. By coming together to fund the installation of large air purifiers, they can make a substantial impact on local air quality. This collective effort could inspire others to join and create a ripple effect throughout the city.  If citizens take the initiative to improve air quality through such projects, it may prompt government officials and politicians to recognize the urgency of the situation and take further action. Public pressure and visible community efforts can lead to more comprehensive policies aimed at reducing pollution. Encouraging collaboration among affluent individuals for social service initiatives like installing air purifiers could not only enhance public health but also motivate governmental bodies to prioritize environmental issues. Affluent individuals often have access to networks that can facilitate large-scale projects. By encouraging collaboration among these individuals, we can create impactful initiatives that not only focus on planting trees but also promote sustainable practices within communities. This could involve forming partnerships with environmental organizations or investing in local community projects aimed at reforestation.The youth represent a significant portion of the population and possess unique capabilities to drive change through social media and grassroots movements. Instead of spending time on activities like dancing on social media reels, young people should be encouraged to engage in environmental activism. This could include organizing local tree-planting events, participating in educational campaigns about the importance of trees, or advocating for policies that support environmental sustainability.

The difference between China and India is that when China is down and out and industrializing, they did not demand that the entire world should pay them 1 trillion dollars as climate finance, unlike India, during COP26 held in Glasgow dated November 2021. This is not a one time example. India being the 5th largest economy of the world, has never hosted the Olympic games when they are poor/rich, unlike China. China had voluntarily made a bid to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for the right to host the Olympic games in year 2008 when they are poor, and once again in the year of 2022 when they are much wealthier. One believes in "the spirit of giving unconditionally" or generosity no matter whether they are rich or poor, the other believes in taking but not sharing/giving. BLAMING OVERPOPULATION FOR DELHI’S AIR POLLUTION OVERSIMPLIFIES THE ISSUE. CITIES LIKE TOKYO AND SHANGHAI, WHICH HAVE LARGER POPULATIONS, MAINTAIN CLEANER AIR DUE TO ADVANCED INFRASTRUCTURE, STRICT ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS, AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. DELHI, HOWEVER, SUFFERS FROM UNDERDEVELOPED PUBLIC TRANSPORT, HEAVY RELIANCE ON PERSONAL VEHICLES, AND A LACK OF ELECTRIC VEHICLE INFRASTRUCTURE. ADDITIONALLY, SEASONAL PRACTICES LIKE STUBBLE BURNING AND THE WIDESPREAD USE OF FIRECRACKERS DURING DIWALI AGGRAVATE POLLUTION. THE REAL PROBLEM LIES IN SYSTEMIC ISSUES LIKE POOR URBAN PLANNING, WEAK POLLUTION CONTROL ENFORCEMENT, AND A FAILURE TO EMBRACE SUSTAINABLE SOLUTIONS.

To ensure pure air and consistently good air quality (AQI below 50) in every Indian city, it is essential to implement a robust Urban Green and Water Plan. This plan would prioritize sustainable urban greenery, water conservation, and eco-friendly infrastructure, creating healthier and cleaner environments for everyone.Urban Green and Water PlanGREEN PLAN :1. Establish a minimum of 40% green cover in every city2. Shady trees should be planted along the central verge and roadsides of every street in the city, providing shade for pedestrians and commuters.3. Implement rain gardens to manage stormwater and enhance biodiversity.4. Create Miyawaki forests in suitable locations to rapidly increase urban green cover.5. Dense plantation of small trees beneath bridges, elevated corridors, and flyovers6. Plant large shade trees, and initiate avenue tree plantation along major roads and public areas.7. Enforce a mandatory provision for residential societies and neighborhoods to maintain at least 40% green space8. Ensure a minimum of 30% greenery in every commercial market, and make it mandatory for all commercial buildings or complexes to dedicate 20% of their space to greenery.Conclusion: The finest example of urbangreenery is ensuring that every available space in the city is utilized for Greenery.Water Plan1. Develop numerous lakes, ponds, and water bodies across the city based on space availability.2. Make rainwater harvesting mandatory for all those using borewells.3. Promote large-scale implementation of water recycling and treatment plants4. Roads in cities should be designed in a way that allows rainwater to flow into the central verge for effective drainage and water conservation.5. Water recharge pits should be constructed throughout the city based on space availability to enhance groundwater replenishment.6. Use permeable materials for pavements and driveways to allow rainwater to infiltrate the ground, reducing runoff and increasing groundwater recharge.7. Conduct regular water audits for homes and businesses to identify areas where water can be conservedConclusion: The best example of waterconservation is to preserve as much water as possible in cities, ensuring that clean water is available at all times and even during extended periods of insufficient rainfall, cities should still have a sufficient supply of water available.

Finally a fair and balanced report mentioning China from Palki. I thank her as a Chinese viewer. Everything she said was correct about China. Our pollution was terrible just a few years go, and it is much better controlled now.  However, please note that it didn't come easy.  The clean-energy push was hard on traditional energy sector, and millions of Chinese factory workers were displaced away from major cities.  To resolve the pollution problem, India needs to make tough choices, and some people's interests and wellbeing will be impacted.  I sincerely wish India can make the tough decision and transition the country on track for sustainable and fast development while managing the fallout from whom that sacrifice along the way.  It would be terrible to get stuck in the endless blaming game between different parties and interest groups where no decision or change can be made.  As neighbors, I hope Chinese and Indian media don't laugh at each other's "tough decisions" and counter-argue every point along the way.  We all face the same challenges and want a better future for our people.

Nothing new.....good content for a news headline!!!!We want luxurious lives with all the facilities, while holding on to our traditions and culture. We love to talk about tradition, culture, and modernization, but we don’t want to put in any effort towards maintaining or improving them. We constantly discuss pollution, unhealthy food, scarcity of resources, and other critical issues like water shortages, waste management problems, and deforestation. But we rarely take any meaningful action.For example, we change our mobile phones every year, not out of necessity but because of fashion. This is just one example of many things we do for show off rather than need. We don't consider the carbon emissions and environmental impact of manufacturing these devices.Some "wise-fool" people (idk what appropriate term do i use for them) talk about the pollution caused by burning crackers during diwali and wood during lohri and holi dahan. Yet, they ignore the massive carbon emissions, producing from every single product, especially plastic ones, that we majorly use and discard or replace merely for the sake of fashion. Plastic is one of the worst (more than worst) contributors to various types of pollution on this planet.There is so much more to say on this topic, but I know this isn’t the right platform for a detailed discussion. One thing is clear: we all need to put in efforts to address these issues. The government alone cant do everything.

That's definitely not what we meant when we said we wanted Delhi to reach world-class standards—not world-high AQI levels.

BLAMING OVERPOPULATION FOR DELHI’S AIR POLLUTION OVERSIMPLIFIES THE ISSUE. CITIES LIKE TOKYO AND SHANGHAI, WHICH HAVE LARGER POPULATIONS, MAINTAIN CLEANER AIR DUE TO ADVANCED INFRASTRUCTURE, STRICT ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS, AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. DELHI, HOWEVER, SUFFERS FROM UNDERDEVELOPED PUBLIC TRANSPORT, HEAVY RELIANCE ON PERSONAL VEHICLES, AND A LACK OF ELECTRIC VEHICLE INFRASTRUCTURE. ADDITIONALLY, SEASONAL PRACTICES LIKE STUBBLE BURNING AND THE WIDESPREAD USE OF FIRECRACKERS DURING DIWALI AGGRAVATE POLLUTION. THE REAL PROBLEM LIES IN SYSTEMIC ISSUES LIKE POOR URBAN PLANNING, WEAK POLLUTION CONTROL ENFORCEMENT, AND A FAILURE TO EMBRACE SUSTAINABLE SOLUTIONS.

It does not make any sense to compare pollution control measures taken up in Beijing and Shanghai with that in Delhi because India has its unique set of problems. Pollution in Beijing and Shanghai rose due to rise in uncontrolled industrial activitied, but with rise in wealth those industries either were relocated or adopted more environment-friendly technologies and measures under strict vigilance of unitary authoritarian government- if awareness campaign and educating the masses failed to yiekd cooperation from them, threat of state violence would certainly yield. Presence of particulate matter in much of north Indian plains has been historically on the higher side relatively due to semi arid nature of soil with powder-like dirt from the open fields carried by the air, Himalayan mountain ranges acting like a natural barrier hindering polluted air from getting swept off which is exaceberated by stagnant air and weak north-westerly monsoon wind in the winter. On top of that lack of communication and rather confrontation among governments run by different political parties most often at loggerheads for ekectoral dividends under federal structure in a multiparty demicracy complicate the problem. Now add to that the unbrudled human action and explore reasons behind that- stubble burning by self-entitled irresponsible semi-literate farmers for short term unburdening of financial loss and they are prone to rioting and also constitute votebank; industrialisation in a developing economy with much lower GDP per capita that on top of corruption and lack of united political will, leads to limited budgetary capacity when it comes to efficient enforcement of law and order, vigilance on pollution control measures by industries, construction sector, transport and businesses and large scale implementation of technological solutions for alternative energy and emission control. India's GDP per capita is almost one fifth of China's- with that kind of GDP per capita, China's industries used to pollute a hell lot 17-18 years back. China also has a cap on migration of chinese people into major cities and financial hubs like Beijing and Shanghai from elsewhere in the country unlike in India where low income groups flock in hordes from neighboring poor states (where GDP per capita hovers between on third and less than half of national average) to a brownfield megacity like Delhi for blue collar jobs in unorganised sectors as lot of such economic activities occur in such cities and these people can not afford cleaner energy solutions for their livelihood (like many of them still burn coal for cooking purposes; even many restaurants in urban India use coal for Tandoors).  India's pollution problems are more complicated than China's and immediate substantial curbing at India's current level of financial capacity would only be possible by certain actions imposed by India's central government that would be ipso facto dubbed by India's political opposition and global media as fascistic, undemocratic, authoritarian, dictatorial, reactionary, nondelegated, impingement on India's federal structure, anti-poor, would hinder economic growth in the short to mid term with businesses shutting down and people losing their jobs and livelihood that in turn would lead to violent protests and riots fomented by politucal brigades with vested interests of returning to power at the center and would be stoked by a milieu of external forces in furthering their own agenda against India. This would be a vicious cycle of no guaranteed succesd given the upjill task but assured chaos and turmoil throughout the country. Are you prepared for that?

If you feel the urge to rub your eyes frequently or if your voice is turning hoarse mid-speech, you can thank the present air for it. It's the same scenario year after year. And it strikes like a clockwork, both in terms of the time of arrival and the impact (AQI always breaches the "severe" category mark) and yet nothing changes except for 20-25 days of annual hue and cry. Btw, we use watered-down version of AQI (NAQI) from that of the western standards (such as: US-EPA). We're already working on a compromised normal. Because apparently when too many people imply "it's okay, chalta hai" to unacceptable things, they become normal. That's how quality of life comes down eventually. This is reflected from the trend of people increasingly willing to shell out extra in the name of getting "pure/organic/chemically untreated" edibles from the market as if purity should be a trait of luxury?Anyway, I recently read that the DPCC chairman refused to give a go ahead to a study by IIT-D to gauge real time sources of pollution in the city. On the other hand, expensive but not very efficient smog towers are lying defunct in central Delhi. Wonder whether consultations were made with the field experts for this project or not. Straw burning from Punjab and Haryana has become more of a mayhem in recent years because this particular agri cycle has been shifted to Oct-Nov by farmers due to groundwater issues in pre-monsoon season. If govt. had the political will or intent, it could've provided some incentives to promote mechanised disposal of straw or linked MSP to straw procurement from farmers but apparently that won't turn out to be a vote-magnet like the electricity freebie. So the truth is, the population at large is also to be blamed for it. But the bigger truth is, there's a larger section of voting population that would choose these freebies over long term solutions for matters such as this. The demographic diversity is such. This, coupled with the fact that the NCR region is a densely populated urban island with several manufacturing industries operating in its satellite cities only add to the problem. But unfortunately the perils are borne by everyone. This makes clean air a luxury in this part of the country. Politicians will always reach for low hanging fruits (short term solutions like GRAP measures) instead of study backed long term solutions that require dedicated investment or best practices which are sustainable year round and also effective rather than disruptive decrees like odd-even rule, or half-hearted measures like closing schools for children upto a certain grade. Government just tries to bide time somehow because they know it's an issue that'll recede in 40-45 days but people tend to underscore the fact that it's an annual affair and even short-term but continous exposure can spur health issues. The ill-effects of polluted air surface gradually and since most of us have memory of a goldfish when it comes to intermittent societal problems (however grave they may be), all is forgotten too soon.Until the better part of the population becomes functional enough to both demand things with a vision and be vociferous enough to let the public representatives know of the same, citizens will just remain a number...a statistic for the electorate. And this fact cuts across party lines so there's no politics here. But the irony is that once we become functional enough on that level, we buy air purifiers for our home, stay put ('coz now many of us can work from our homes or if not, then work in AC offices), order things from q-commerce and get along with our cocooned lives. Now we don't have time for the political crap. But the show goes on...because the show always goes on : )

Highly polluted air again hangs over Delhi-NCR this year, affecting the health of millions in the region. Earlier this week, the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) predicted that Air Quality Index (AQI) will be “very poor” in the coming days, with Delhi’s AQI expected to hover between 400 and 500. AQI of 0-50 is considered good, and 51-100 satisfactory. The Air Quality Index (AQI) scal 51-100 (satisfactory), 101-200 (moderate), 201-300 (poor), 301-400 (very poor), and 401-500 (severe).“The pollution in Delhi this time of the year is deadly & frustrating,”Dr Naresh Trehan, CMD of Medanta Hospital, Gurgaon. “I can tell just by looking at a patient’ s lungs whether they live in the city or near the Oceans,” he says, noting that the lungs of Delhi-NCR residents often turn dark grey or black. 𝕵𝖆𝖎 𝕳𝖆𝖓𝖚𝖒𝖆𝖓𝖙𝖊!!!Cancer cases in India increased at an average annual rate of 2 per cent between 2010 & 2019Cut to the 21st century & it's doubled & we witness the same lack of urgency & continued complacency around cancer in Indians. Let us deal with some hard numbers to set the Context. At present, there are 1.38 million new cases of cancer in India. As many as 1,392,179 people in India had cancer in 2020, according to a global oncology report.According to another report, cancer cases in India increased at an average annual rate of 2 per cent between 2010 & 2019. Cancer cases have doubled in just three years. Deaths from cancer in the country also went up at an average rate of 0.1 to 1 per cent in the same period.To add to the concern, India's growth rates for cancer are among the highest globally, making India an unenviable candidate for being the cancer capital of the world.Around 80 to 85 per cent of cancer cases in India are related to extreme air, water pollution& tobacco products.Four hundred Indian women die from cervical cancer every day. The top four cancersraging in India includes breast, cervix, lungs & oral. However, many of the most common types of cancer affecting India are preventable cancers. Clean air & water, non pesticide food, Early detection & subsequent prevention policies & programmes can stem this deluge before it turns into a tsunami of monstrous proportions.We need dedicated social workers & paramedics as well as government subsidiesSubsidising essential cancer screening programme payments can be an important part of the cancer prevention mechanismcost? Emotions and ethics apart, purely from a business standpoint, preventing cancer among millions of underprivileged Indians will probably add more value to the economy than buildingCorporate hospitals that mostIndians cannot afford.This brings us to clean air, water pollution, non pesticide food & tobacco usage. The scourge that continues to inflict carnage onIndian cities, despite statutory warnings, roadside hoardings & media advertisements and updates of air quality across cities. How about taking it to the next level & documenting the adverse effects of air, water pollution, deadly effects of pesticide loaded food, tobacco chewing & nicotinesmoking as part of national school curricula? How about routine oral check ups & lung cancer screening for those at risk?At the end of the day, what are we trying to accomplish? We are trying to create a mindset of awareness where early detection & warning signs, timely screenings & subsequent prevention become the fulcrum of cancer management.In short, it's life-saving to nip cancer in the bud. Cities of India have become a ticking time bomb when it comes to deadly life threatening disease directly related to air, water & pesticides related pollution. Finally it's never the governments but individuals who got to safeguard their families health & lives. Be Brave. Be free. Take the decisions. It's 100% in your hands. 𝓣𝓱𝓮 𝓡𝓲𝓼𝓼𝓪𝓵𝓪 : India's 10 most polluted cities in October all in NCRAll the top 10 most polluted cities of India were from Delhi-National Capital Region in Oct, according to an analysis by Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA). Delhi was the most polluted city in the country in Oct with an average PM2.5 concentration of 111 micrograms per cubic metre, followed by Ghaziabad at 110 and Muzaffarnagar at 103. CREA monitored 263 cities in the country, whose pollution data on continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations was available for 80% of the year's days.According to the analysis, Ghaziabad, Muzaffarnagar, Hapur, Noida, Meerut, Charkhi Dadri, Greater Noida, Gurgaon and Bahadurgarh, all NCR cities, were identified as the second to tenth most polluted cities in India. "This alarming ranking persists despite the implementation of the Graded Response Action Plan, which has been in effect since Oct 15," said CREA."With the exception of Delhi, all other megacities such as Chennai, Mumbai, Kolkata and Bengaluru managed to maintain PM2.5 values below the national standard in Oct," said CREA.CREA added that for the first time this year, Uttar Pradesh dominated the list of India's top 10 most polluted cities, with six cities in the state making the list, followed by three from Haryana. All these 10 cities recorded PM2.5 levels way higher than the daily national ambient air quality standard of 60 micrograms per cubic metre and WHO's daily safe guideline of 15 micrograms per cubic metre.𝓣𝓱𝓮 𝓡𝓲𝓼𝓼𝓪𝓵𝓪.: Air pollution is indeed deadly, posing one of the greatest global health threats today. With harmful pollutants such as particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide, and sulfur dioxide saturating the air, millions of people are exposed to invisible toxins everyday. Speaking of pollution, One Asian city has recorded an alarming Air Quality Index (AQI) of 1,165 on Wednesday, as per Swiss air quality monitoring group IQAir, which aggregates data from 14 regional monitoring stations. This level is over 120 times higher than the air quality standards recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO).

BLAMING OVERPOPULATION FOR DELHI’S AIR POLLUTION OVERSIMPLIFIES THE ISSUE. CITIES LIKE TOKYO AND SHANGHAI, WHICH HAVE LARGER POPULATIONS, MAINTAIN CLEANER AIR DUE TO ADVANCED INFRASTRUCTURE, STRICT ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS, AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. DELHI, HOWEVER, SUFFERS FROM UNDERDEVELOPED PUBLIC TRANSPORT, HEAVY RELIANCE ON PERSONAL VEHICLES, AND A LACK OF ELECTRIC VEHICLE INFRASTRUCTURE. ADDITIONALLY, SEASONAL PRACTICES LIKE STUBBLE BURNING AND THE WIDESPREAD USE OF FIRECRACKERS DURING DIWALI AGGRAVATE POLLUTION. THE REAL PROBLEM LIES IN SYSTEMIC ISSUES LIKE POOR URBAN PLANNING, WEAK POLLUTION CONTROL ENFORCEMENT, AND A FAILURE TO EMBRACE SUSTAINABLE SOLUTIONS.

If you feel the urge to rub your eyes frequently or if your voice is turning hoarse mid-speech, you can thank the present air for it. It's the same scenario year after year. And it strikes like a clockwork, both in terms of the time of arrival and the impact (AQI always breaches the "severe" category mark) and yet nothing changes except for 20-25 days of annual hue and cry. Btw, we use watered-down version of AQI (NAQI) from that of the western standards (such as: US-EPA). We're already working on a compromised normal. Because apparently when too many people imply "it's okay, chalta hai" to unacceptable things, they become normal. That's how quality of life comes down eventually. This is reflected from the trend of people increasingly willing to shell out extra in the name of getting "pure/organic/chemically untreated" edibles from the market as if purity should be a trait of luxury?Anyway, I recently read that the DPCC chairman refused to give a go ahead to a study by IIT-D to gauge real time sources of pollution in the city. On the other ahead, expensive but not very efficient smog towers are lying defunct in central Delhi. Wonder whether consultations were made with the field experts for this project or not. Straw burning from Punjab and Haryana has become more of a mayhem in recent years because this particular agri cycle has been shifted to Oct-Nov by farmers due to groundwater issues in pre-monsoon season. If govt. had the political will or intent, it could've provided some incentives to promote mechanised disposal of straw or linked MSP to straw procurement from farmers but apparently that won't turn out to be a vote-magnet like the electricity freebie. So the truth is, the population at large is also to be blamed for it. But the bigger truth is, there's a larger section of voting population that would choose these freebies over long term solutions for matters such as this. The demographic diversity is such. This, coupled with the fact that the NCR region is a densely populated urban island with several manufacturing industries operating in its satellite cities only add to the problem. But unfortunately the perils are borne by everyone. This makes clean air a luxury in this part of the country. Politicians will always reach for low hanging fruits (short term solutions like GRAP measures) instead of study backed long term solutions that require dedicated investment or best practices which are sustainable year round and also effective rather than disruptive decrees like odd-even rule, or half-hearted measures like closing schools for children upto a certain grade. Government just tries to bide time somehow because they know it's an issue that'll recede in 40-45 days but people tend to underscore the fact that it's an annual affair and even short-term but continous exposure can spur health issues. The ill-effects of polluted air surface gradually but since most of us have memory of a goldfish when it comes to intermittent societal problems (however grave they may be), all is forgotten too soon.Until the better part of the population becomes functional enough to both demand things with a vision and be vociferous enough to let the public representatives know of the same, citizens will just remain a number...a statistic for the electorate. And this fact cuts across party lines so there's no politics here. But the irony is that once we become functional enough on that level, we buy air purifiers for our home, stay put ('coz now many of us can work from our homes or if not, then work in AC offices), order things from q-commerce and get along with our cocooned lives. Now we don't have time for the political crap. But the show goes on...because the show always goes on : )

You’ve touched on a complex issue that involves a mix of urbanization, commercialization, governance, and environmental factors. Delhi’s pollution is a multifaceted problem with multiple contributors, as you rightly pointed out. Let’s break down the issues you raised:1. Excessive Commercialization and OverpopulationDelhi, as the capital of India, has seen rapid urbanization and commercialization over the last few decades. This has led to an influx of people from all parts of the country seeking better employment opportunities, education, and access to resources like electricity and water. The migration often results in overcrowding, straining existing infrastructure and resources, and further contributing to pollution.Increased vehicle numbers: More people mean more vehicles on the roads, leading to traffic congestion, longer idling times, and higher emissions. The constant influx of people means more construction and more demand for services, which intensifies the pollution problem.Strain on resources: The demand for free electricity and water can put a significant strain on the resources of the city, leading to overexploitation, which has its own environmental cost. At times, there’s also excessive use of diesel generators due to power shortages, contributing further to air pollution.2. Illegal or Legal Hawkers on FootpathsStreet vendors, whether legal or illegal, occupy large parts of Delhi’s footpaths. This creates several problems:Obstruction of footpaths: When hawkers occupy footpaths, pedestrians are forced onto roads, which causes congestion and often leads to more vehicles stopping unnecessarily on roads. This also results in traffic snarls and increases fuel consumption and emissions from idling cars.Air and noise pollution: Many hawkers use makeshift stoves and generators to power their stalls, which can contribute to air pollution. The noise generated by the crowded areas, along with the idling vehicles, adds to the pollution burden.Waste generation: Vendors, especially food vendors, often create a lot of waste, some of which is not disposed of properly. This leads to littering and contributes to the pollution, especially around busy markets and commercial areas.3. Unnecessary Construction and Infrastructure DevelopmentThe issue of unchecked construction is another significant driver of pollution. Authorities sometimes approve projects that are poorly planned or unnecessary, often driven by the interests of contractors and real estate developers.Dust and particulate matter: Construction activities, especially when not managed well, release large amounts of dust and particulate matter into the air, which directly impacts air quality. This is particularly damaging to health, as PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) levels increase, which are linked to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases.Encroachment and disruption: Unnecessary construction projects often lead to the encroachment of green spaces and open areas. Trees and vegetation, which act as natural filters for pollutants, are cleared for buildings, roads, or commercial complexes. This reduces the city’s capacity to absorb air pollutants.Disruptions and inefficiencies: Construction activities can disrupt traffic, increase congestion, and lead to longer travel times. These inefficiencies in urban planning add to the pollution by increasing fuel consumption and emissions.4. Government Policies and EnforcementWhile the government has made efforts to address pollution through various measures like vehicle emission standards, odd-even schemes, promoting electric vehicles, and improving public transportation, enforcement remains a challenge.Lack of enforcement: Even though laws exist to regulate hawkers, vehicle emissions, construction activities, and waste management, enforcement is often weak. Political and bureaucratic challenges often result in poor implementation of these laws, leading to more pollution.Short-term solutions: Many policies address the symptoms rather than the root causes. For instance, initiatives like the odd-even rule or the shutting down of industries for a few days may reduce pollution temporarily but fail to address the long-term structural causes.Solutions and Way ForwardThere’s no single solution, but a combination of strategies could help alleviate the problem:Urban Planning: Better urban planning, with a focus on sustainable growth, efficient public transportation, and pedestrian-friendly infrastructure, could reduce congestion and pollution. Zoning regulations should be enforced more strictly to ensure that commercial activity doesn’t spill over into public spaces like footpaths.Hawker Regulation: Rather than cracking down on hawkers, the government could look at creating designated spaces for them where they don’t obstruct footpaths or roads. This would reduce congestion and ensure that street vendors are able to work without contributing to pollution.Construction Oversight: Stricter oversight and regulation of construction projects, ensuring that they follow environmental norms and manage dust pollution effectively, would help mitigate the environmental impact.Awareness Campaigns: Public awareness campaigns can encourage people to reduce their reliance on private vehicles, use public transport, and adopt more eco-friendly practices.Greening Delhi: The government could invest in increasing green spaces, promoting rooftop gardens, and planting more trees to help absorb pollutants and provide a buffer against heat and dust.Delhi’s pollution is undoubtedly a significant challenge, but a more coordinated and holistic approach could reduce its impact. As with many urban issues, tackling the problem requires the collaboration of citizens, businesses, and the government to create a healthier, more sustainable city.

You’ve touched on a complex issue that involves a mix of urbanization, commercialization, governance, and environmental factors. Delhi’s pollution is a multifaceted problem with multiple contributors, as you rightly pointed out. Let’s break down the issues you raised:1. Excessive Commercialization and OverpopulationDelhi, as the capital of India, has seen rapid urbanization and commercialization over the last few decades. This has led to an influx of people from all parts of the country seeking better employment opportunities, education, and access to resources like electricity and water. The migration often results in overcrowding, straining existing infrastructure and resources, and further contributing to pollution.Increased vehicle numbers: More people mean more vehicles on the roads, leading to traffic congestion, longer idling times, and higher emissions. The constant influx of people means more construction and more demand for services, which intensifies the pollution problem.Strain on resources: The demand for free electricity and water can put a significant strain on the resources of the city, leading to overexploitation, which has its own environmental cost. At times, there’s also excessive use of diesel generators due to power shortages, contributing further to air pollution.2. Illegal or Legal Hawkers on FootpathsStreet vendors, whether legal or illegal, occupy large parts of Delhi’s footpaths. This creates several problems:Obstruction of footpaths: When hawkers occupy footpaths, pedestrians are forced onto roads, which causes congestion and often leads to more vehicles stopping unnecessarily on roads. This also results in traffic snarls and increases fuel consumption and emissions from idling cars.Air and noise pollution: Many hawkers use makeshift stoves and generators to power their stalls, which can contribute to air pollution. The noise generated by the crowded areas, along with the idling vehicles, adds to the pollution burden.Waste generation: Vendors, especially food vendors, often create a lot of waste, some of which is not disposed of properly. This leads to littering and contributes to the pollution, especially around busy markets and commercial areas.3. Unnecessary Construction and Infrastructure DevelopmentThe issue of unchecked construction is another significant driver of pollution. Authorities sometimes approve projects that are poorly planned or unnecessary, often driven by the interests of contractors and real estate developers.Dust and particulate matter: Construction activities, especially when not managed well, release large amounts of dust and particulate matter into the air, which directly impacts air quality. This is particularly damaging to health, as PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) levels increase, which are linked to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases.Encroachment and disruption: Unnecessary construction projects often lead to the encroachment of green spaces and open areas. Trees and vegetation, which act as natural filters for pollutants, are cleared for buildings, roads, or commercial complexes. This reduces the city’s capacity to absorb air pollutants.Disruptions and inefficiencies: Construction activities can disrupt traffic, increase congestion, and lead to longer travel times. These inefficiencies in urban planning add to the pollution by increasing fuel consumption and emissions.4. Government Policies and EnforcementWhile the government has made efforts to address pollution through various measures like vehicle emission standards, odd-even schemes, promoting electric vehicles, and improving public transportation, enforcement remains a challenge.Lack of enforcement: Even though laws exist to regulate hawkers, vehicle emissions, construction activities, and waste management, enforcement is often weak. Political and bureaucratic challenges often result in poor implementation of these laws, leading to more pollution.Short-term solutions: Many policies address the symptoms rather than the root causes. For instance, initiatives like the odd-even rule or the shutting down of industries for a few days may reduce pollution temporarily but fail to address the long-term structural causes.Solutions and Way ForwardThere’s no single solution, but a combination of strategies could help alleviate the problem:Urban Planning: Better urban planning, with a focus on sustainable growth, efficient public transportation, and pedestrian-friendly infrastructure, could reduce congestion and pollution. Zoning regulations should be enforced more strictly to ensure that commercial activity doesn’t spill over into public spaces like footpaths.Hawker Regulation: Rather than cracking down on hawkers, the government could look at creating designated spaces for them where they don’t obstruct footpaths or roads. This would reduce congestion and ensure that street vendors are able to work without contributing to pollution.Construction Oversight: Stricter oversight and regulation of construction projects, ensuring that they follow environmental norms and manage dust pollution effectively, would help mitigate the environmental impact.Awareness Campaigns: Public awareness campaigns can encourage people to reduce their reliance on private vehicles, use public transport, and adopt more eco-friendly practices.Greening Delhi: The government could invest in increasing green spaces, promoting rooftop gardens, and planting more trees to help absorb pollutants and provide a buffer against heat and dust.Delhi’s pollution is undoubtedly a significant challenge, but a more coordinated and holistic approach could reduce its impact. As with many urban issues, tackling the problem requires the collaboration of citizens, businesses, and the government to create a healthier, more sustainable city.

One thing that I noted through the image shared by NASA is that almost 95% of Farm Fires were in Punjab alone & Haryana & UP had very few pockets where we could see the red dots (depicting Farm fire).So why can't AAP Government in Punjab also follow the Haryana model of renting out stubble collection to Private Agencies & renting out machines involved in cutting stubble at subsidized rates to farmers.If Punjab Government across all parties have given subsidies on Water, Electricity & what not, I am sure subsidies can be given on this noble initiative too that will help atleast Delhi Government (in projecting it has successfully tackled pollution) if not others + profitable for Farmers & would give rise to farm based businesses like Ethanol Industries, Cardboard based industries, creating employment.Another thing that Government across all levels, specially at the Municipal Level can focus on would be investing in Road Cleaners & Water Spinklers.This will also help reduce pollution as well to a big extent & another benefit might be that it would make our cities clean, improving their overall tourism potential.Third could obviously be stricter pollution control norms for Industries, specially those Industries that are looking to get established in NCR (not solely Delhi as pollution affects entire NCR). This again would come under respective State Governments.If these 3 things are taken care of by respective governments, atleast 60-70% of pollution problem would be tackled providing a major relief to citizens living in NCR.

I am currently doing government internship under CRM (Crop residue management) scheme-2023 in Haryana and government is doing a lot of work in this matter. Providing machines on subsidy, regular interactions with farmers, beneficiaries and custom hiring centres. Spreading awareness, organizing camps in each and every village of haryana. Hiring interns and staff for additional help in the harvest season. And all this hardwork is paying off. Ofcourse we still have a very long way to go. Some problems are - not enough facilities/industries to process stubble (exsitu management), financial problem of farmers, local political agendas, less punishment to farmers who burn stubble, life risk factor on agricuture officers who try to stop burning onsite,unsuccessful pusa decomposers, happy seeder, etc.

What I have learnt from this video ! To address pollution in Delhi, various measures can be implemented:1. Promote Sustainable Transportation:Promote walking, bicycling, and public transportation as ways to cut down on vehicle emissions. Invest in environmentally responsible and effective public transit options.2. Strict Emission Standards:Enforce and regularly update stringent emission standards for industries and vehicles to limit air pollutants.3. Green Spaces:Increase the number of green spaces and urban forests to absorb pollutants and improve overall air quality.4. Waste Management:Implement effective waste management systems to reduce open burning of waste, a significant contributor to air pollution.5.Renewable Energy Promotion:Encourage the adoption of renewable energy sources for power generation to reduce reliance on fossil fuels.6.Awareness Campaigns:Conduct public awareness campaigns to educate people about the impact of pollution and promote responsible behavior.7. Crop Residue Management:Address agricultural practices contributing to air pollution, especially stubble burning. Promote alternative methods for crop residue disposal.8. Stricter Construction Regulations:Implement and enforce construction guidelines to minimize dust emissions at construction sites.9. Air Quality Monitoring:Invest in a robust air quality monitoring system to track pollution levels and take timely actions based on real-time data.10. Community Engagement:Involve the community in pollution control efforts, encouraging responsible practices and reporting violations.For individuals, adopting eco-friendly practices like carpooling, reducing energy consumption, and proper waste disposal can contribute to pollution control. Sorry to say but i disagree with your cracker point. In the whole video you concentrated only on delhi’s air pollution. But about places like mumbai which are covered by sea from 3 sides and there is no stubble burning in the neighbouring states. And even if they were, the air wouldn’t be coming towards mumbai as the winds blows in the opposite direction. Also you forgot the fact that the companies making fire crackers start polluting the air even before the diwali arives. The pollution created because of making of these crackers is also equivalent to 1/3 of the total pollution made by vehicles in the whole year. Also those 5 days of diwali, make pollution equivalent to 2/4 of the total pollution from different sources in the year. AFAIK diwali was supposed to be festival of lights rather then festival of fireworks. During my childhood, i grew up watching people wearing colourful clothes, doing colourful rangolis, lighting up diyas, putting colour full lights and lanterns. I never saw people bursting crackers on such large scales. It is just that people have taken to their ego now a days, they just want to show off how much they are capable of spending on firecrackers. These same people would cry for money the 360 days of the year and then spend their savings in those 5 days to show off. I see people wasting 10k per day on firecrackers. I agree on most of what you said but simply saying that people don't use public transport because it is uncool is a false statement. Other serious reasons for people not using public transport are - 1. Safety in public transport2. Public transport in Delhi might be very good but it is still not the most convenient method to travel in every case since it might take a person 15-20 min walk or an auto to reach the metro station followed by changing trains to reach the destination. People would always prefer more convenient methods over showoff. As of now personal vehicles are still more convenient to reach from point A to point B instead of taking multiple trains/buses followed by autos/walking. This is similar to taking a direct flight (also called the point to point model) instead of flying to a hub and then taking another flight to reach your final destination. I agree that driving is Delhi is also not the most convenient thing.I am curious to know if late at night when there are comparatively less number of vehicles on road, do we see an impact on the AQI. Where I live during peak traffic hours the AQI was ~460 the other day, whereas at 1:40am the AQI was still above 430 which to me indicates that vehicles might not have as big of an impact as people might claim

Hi Abhi and Niyu,I always look forward to your videos and was expecting this video too.Just wanted to share my recent experience with you. As I am associated with Travel and Tourism industry, I have to travel different countries for tourism purposes. Visited Singapore couple of months back. I came across a video in any other YT channel regarding How Singapore Keeps their air clean.I rechecked with my co-workers in Singapore that is that really true. They replied every night their garbages and other stuffs are being gathered and collected by the Environment Cleaners and they dump everything into a burning pit. Slowly the garbages are burnt and the smoke gets purified by the air purifiers. The clean O2 is released in the air to breathe in and the left over residuals are recycled and gets used for various production works. Such a simple process and effective.This can be a solution for us too if the blame game players actually gets serious about the issues.

Mere pass kuch solutions hai, rather suggestions bol sakte hai - 1. Vehicle related problem. - I am from a small town coochbehar, but I live in Kolkata for education. Here I see a lot of uppermiddle class people traveling in their own economy segment cars ( under 30 lakh, mostly costing around 10-15lakh) with one or two seats occupied. As we know these days car owing become easy for any one because of EMI system. The government should bring a plan like for private buyer companies can not sell IC cars under 30 lakh only electric or hydrogen cars can be sold. Because of this the owner ship figures will drop drastically. And all the comercial cars should be running on CNG. This way polution Will be cut down in half. Buses that runs in routes less than 100km should be swapped with elctric buses.( Obviously will take atleast 10 years). Some would argue that cars are important. No my friend its not a necessity its luxury. If I can live without car you too can. Whenever needed you just rent a electric or cng cab.2. Stubble burning. - one thing govt can do is provide the farmers with machine which can uproot those stubble. And mix that with soil. ( Basically koi machine se mitti aur stubble ko milwa do jisse wo niche ajay aur niche ka mitti upar ajay. Aur wo jo stubble ho ga wo automatically pach jayga aur fertilizer ka kam karega. Specially nitrogen fertilizer ki jarurat nehi padegi tab. 3. Increase oxygen-  very few people know that moss produce tons of oxygen. So instead of using fake grass wall for decoration in building or places. Use moss wall ( maybe some company makes or will make, this is just my idea) for decoration. Moss wall will keep your building cool too and will release a lot of oxygen into the environment.4. Industrial polution.  - look indias small and large scale industries are centralised in different hotspots of India. Govt should bring a law that will control the industrialisation of that area.  There should be a limit in the number of factory in any city and surrounding areas . If de centralisation of industries happen then many small villages, and town will also be benifited as the companies will setup plant in those areas instead of crowded urban areas.

In addition to banning firecrackers, some things that could be banned to reduce air pollution include:  Aerosols: Aerosols use CFCs, which are air pollutants. Construction debris: The Bombay High Court ordered a temporary halt to the movement of construction debris to and from construction sites until Diwali. Old cars: Governments should tackle air pollution by banning old cars.Other things you can do to reduce air pollution include:  Reducing the number of trips you take in your car Reducing or eliminating fireplace and wood stove use Avoiding burning leaves, trash, and other materials Avoiding using gas-powered lawn and garden equipment Using public transports Turning off the lights when not in use Recycling and reusing Reducing forest fires and smoking

Banning firecrackers is one way to make the air cleaner, but it is not enough. There are many other things that make the air dirty and harm our health. Some of these things are: 1 ) Cars and trucks that use oil and gas. They make a lot of smoke and bad gases that make us cough and breathe hard. We can use less of them and use buses, trains, bikes, or electric cars instead 2: . Factories and farms that make smoke and chemicals. They make the air smell bad and can cause diseases like cancer. We can make them follow rules to stop or reduce their smoke and chemicals 3: . Wood and cow dung that make black dust when used for cooking and heating. They make the air inside our homes dirty and can cause problems like asthma and lung infections. We can use gas, biogas, or electric stoves instead 4: . Plastic that makes bad smells when burned or thrown away. It can also harm animals and plants. We can avoid using plastic things that we use only once, like bags, spoons, and plates, and use cloth, metal, or paper things instead

I could not have anticipated the amount of belligerent racism, bigotry and disrespect that I’d get to see in these comments. Do you folks think that Delhi - the tiny city that’s surrounded by hundreds of square kilometers of agricultural land that undergoes seasonal crop burning - could have had a big role to play in either causing or containing the air pollution? Yeah I didn’t realize that no one would bother to know how or why this situation has happened, most of yall are just brain-rotted trolls who sit behind your computer screens and make a day out of taking a dump on the Internet. I didn’t see a single comment expressing empathy for the residents of Delhi who have to put up with this nonsense because they’re powerless against the large intensive- farming communities that surround the capital territory. And the BBC never fails to show up whenever they get the chance to make most of the hardships that people around the world are facing. I’m not saying that they should not report on this - by all means, it’s essential that they bring light to stuff like this, in hope that it might nudge politicians to do something about it. Strategies for Eradicating PollutionTo combat pollution effectively, individuals must make conscious changes in their daily habits. The following recommendations can help:1. Energy Conservation: Minimize electrical appliance usage and opt for energy-efficient devices.2. Water Conservation: Reduce water consumption and implement conservation methods.3. Waste Management: Segregate and recycle waste.4. Reduced Vehicle Emissions: Utilize public transportation or walk/cycle.5. Reforestation: Planting trees mitigates air pollution.6. Sustainable Agriculture: Adopt organic farming practices to minimize chemical usage.7. Proper Waste Disposal: Ensure responsible waste management.8. Education and Awareness: Promote pollution awareness and education.9. Supporting Government Initiatives: Endorse policies aimed at reducing pollution.10. Personal Accountability: Take responsibility for reducing pollution in daily life.Implementing these strategies can eradicate pollution and pave the way for a cleaner, healthier future."

I used to stay in Delhi NCR as a kid till 2012. There was barely any air pollution back then. Returned to Gurgaon last year and I was saddened by the change in the last decade. All the pollution fiasco started in 2014-15 and unfortunately the blame game between Delhi govt and central govt has horribly transformed Delhi’s as well as India’s image. The right kind of measures are never even discusses, let alone be implemented and instead common man is made to suffer by banning BS3/4 vehicles on the road even though they have passed the  mandatory PUC check to be deemed fit to run on the road. I hope some sane person takes control of this situation and we do not normalise this as a living standard. We have been raising awareness regarding this since ages but nothing has happened yet. If this continues, then in the next decade or two, Delhi would be unlivable and that’s unfortunate for a city that has a rich source of history and is of course the capital of the fastest growing nation in the world.

"Delhi's pollution crisis is a classic example of putting too many eggs in one basket. Despite having adequate infrastructure, people suffer daily due to unbearable traffic jams, lack of parking, overcrowded roads, inadequate public transport, and rising pollution levels. Adding to this is the lack of civic sense among citizens, further worsening the chaos.Take the period between Deepavali and Chhath Puja as an example — roads are empty, and pollution levels drop significantly. This proves how much of Delhi’s population is migrant. So why can’t the government take bold steps to decentralize? Shift non-essential offices and organizations to smaller towns across India.Delhi, as the capital, can host essential offices, but the rest can operate from anywhere, just as ISRO thrives in Bangalore and successfully launched Chandrayaan. Pilani, a remote Rajasthan village, earned global recognition with BITS. Decentralization will not only reduce the pressure on Delhi but also foster development in smaller towns. Bold action is overdue — decentralize, redistribute, and relieve Delhi."#DelhiPollution #DecentralizeDevelopment #SustainableGrowth

I lived in China when it was horrible there (Beijing) and I can testify it's the worst. I recall a pregnant lady walking into our office wearing an advanced mask, at that point I hadn't seen such masks ever. Soon, while looking outside my office but not able to see 50 meters far, I realized it was time to buy a mask myself. I felt that the air inside the mask was almost as horrible as the air outside. I felt like I could almost taste the outside air, and the "filtered air" inside my mask was not only smelly but also moisty. Whenever I took off my mask I had the lines imprinted on my face. However, what was the worst about it, was that (just like during COVID) you didn't get to see people's expressions. With everyone's faces hidden, there were no friendly encounters on the street. I almost felt like I was in a country inhabited by robots where it was each to themselves. We will only know later on what the toll of living in pollution for years will truly be. My heart goes out to all who have to live in such conditions,, often without protection such as masks and air purifiers, neither health insurance.

To all those njoying the news - nature is a great equalizer or do you think climate changes will not affect developed nations in future?.. this time of year in the northern belt of India and Pakistan, the temperature are dropping but there is no breeze which causes particulate material to settle down ...those who can afford rely on air purifiers in cars,  home, and schools...but it is the poor who suffer the most...but I see no solution in sight...govt and citizens both prioritize other problems over this..as someone who lives in Delhi-NCR, I have resigned myself to the fact that this problem is here to stay and irrespective of political party that we select, we cannot do much about it..may be just control it at a level through punitive measures (I would like to see a govt that puts an end to crop stubble burning, construction activity stoppage, permanent ban on firecrackers and one with full scale reducing dust project but none of the govt irrespective of political affiliation have will power to do this currently...but a time will come when people will not be able to ignore this)
